questions.text: During the evaluation of a patient posted for emergency appendicectomy, the anesthetist grades him as Mallampatti class III and suspects a difficult airway. The device given in the image below can be used in this patient. The disadvantage of this device compared to an endotracheal intubation is:

choices.text: Risk of aspiration of gastric contents

questions.solution:
The given image shows a laryngeal mask airway (LMA) which is indicated in cases with difficult airways. The disadvantage of LMA is that it increases the risk of aspiration of gastric contents.

LMA is used for airway management as a temporary, life-saving measure in patients with difficult ventilation. Difficult ventilation can be either due to difficult airways, unavailability, or difficulty in mask ventilation and intubation.

Advantages of LMA:

  • Less invasive as compared to tracheal tubes.
  • Lesser bronchospasm as compared to tracheal tubes 
  • It partially protects the larynx from pharyngeal secretions.
  • Useful in difficult intubations
  • Less trauma to teeth and pharynx
  • Muscle relaxation is not required
  • Neck mobility is not required 

Disadvantages:

  • does not protect from gastric regurgitation
  • Less safe in prone or jack-knife positions
  • Less secure airway
  • Greater risk of a gas leak and pollution

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of Laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

Indication:

  • Difficult airway management during cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
  • In emergency where intubation & mask ventilation is not possible. 
  • For minor surgeries, where Anesthetist wants to avoid intubation. 
  • As a conduit for bronchoscopes, small size tubes, gum elastic bougies.

Contraindications:

  • Oropharyngeal abscess or mass
  • Poor mouth opening 
  • Conditions with high risk of aspiration:
    • Hiatus hernia
    • Pregnancy
    • Full stomach patients who are vulnerable to go in bronchospasm
    • Low pulmonary compliance (eg. Obesity)
    • Peak inspiratory pressure > 30 cm of H2O.

questions.text: While posted in the COVID ward, you notice the following instruments present on a tray and you realize it is for a particular procedure. All of the following predict difficulty in performing the procedure except:
questions.solution:
The image shows a tray in an airway cart with the instruments necessary for endotracheal intubation. All the options are predictors of difficult laryngoscopy (and difficult intubation) except a long, thin neck. A short, thick neck is a predictor of difficult laryngoscopy.

An endotracheal intubation tray may include:

  1. Magill's forceps 
  2. Macintosh curved laryngoscope/Miller's straight laryngoscope for direct laryngoscopy
  3. Endotracheal (ET) tubes of varying sizes
  4. A 10ml syringe to inflate the bulb of the ET tube
  5. Stylet and Bougie to aid in difficulty with intubation
  6. Guedel oropharyngeal airway to suction secretion for better visualization of the airway

Difficult endotracheal intubation by direct laryngoscopy is primarily due to an inadequate view of the glottis. Predictors for difficult laryngoscopy are as given below :

  • Long upper incisors
  • Prominent overbite
  • Inability to protrude the mandible
  • Small mouth opening
  • Mallampati classification III or IV
  • High, arched palate
  • Short thyromental distance
  • Short, thick neck
  • Limited cervical mobility

The Cormack and Lehane grading scale describes laryngoscopic views with grades ranging from I (the best view) to IV (the most difficult view). The grades are as follows :

Grades Structures visualized
I Entire laryngeal aperture
II Only the posterior portion of the laryngeal aperture
III Only the epiglottis
IV No visualization of the epiglottis or larynx

Yentis modified the classification scheme and proposed that grade II be differentiated into IIA (partial view of the glottis) and IIB (arytenoids or posterior vocal cords only are visible).

  • Grade I or IIA - relatively easy intubation.
  • Grades IIB and III - significantly difficult intubation.
  • Grade IV- alternate method of intubation required (such as blind passage of ET or using an intubating stylet).

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: In an intubated patient, after what duration of endotracheal intubation will you need to perform a tracheostomy?
questions.solution:
Tracheostomy is performed in an intubated patient after 2-3 weeks.

This is because if an orotracheal or nasotracheal tube is left in situ for more than 2-3 weeks, it results in subglottic stenosis.

Hence it is ideal to replace the endotracheal tube with a cuffed tracheostomy tube.

If on intubation, it is perceived that the patient may require intubation for a period longer than 2 weeks, then tracheostomy can be performed soon after intubation.

Tracheostomy has been found to reduce the incidence of pneumonia, the duration of mechanical ventilation, and the length of stay in hospitals for patients with major head injuries.

questions.text: A patient is posted for an ambulatory surgery and the following agent is used for intravenous induction of anesthesia. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the agent shown in the image below?

choices.text: It causes pain on intravenous injection
Increases the risk of post-operative nausea and vomiting
Used as sedation for mechanically ventilated patients

questions.solution:
The anesthetic agent used in this patient for induction is propofol which appears as a milky white liquid as shown in the image. Propofol has antiemetic properties which help reduce post-operative nausea and vomiting.

Its constituents are:

  • 1% propofol
  • 1.2% egg phospholipid (emulsifier)
  • 2.25% glycerol (Tonicity adjusting agent)
  • 10% soya bean oil 
  • NaOH (to change pH)
  • EDTA (bacteriostatic)

Propofol is formulated as a lipid emulsion, which causes pain on injection. A new aqueous prodrug, fospropofol is associated with less pain on injection. Propofol should be handled with sterile techniques as it has a risk of growth of bacteria.

Propofol facilitates the inhibitory neurotransmission by action on GABA-A receptors. It has a rapid onset of action (within 15 sec). Induction dose is usually 1-2 mg/ kg and maintenance dose is 100-200 µg/ kg/ min.

Effects on CNS:

  • It is cerebro-protective. Reduces intracranial pressure and cerebral blood flow.
  • Anticonvulsant properties
  • Has anti-emetic properties at a dose of 10-20mg.

Other effects:

  • Produce hypotension and bradycardia; hence dose reduction is needed in elderly and hypovolemic patients.
  • Produce apnea since it is a profound respiratory depressant. 
  • Anti-pruritic property
  • Propofol infusion syndrome: It is a rare syndrome that can happen when propofol is used for long-term sedation in young patients who are critically ill or underwent neurosurgery. Symptoms include metabolic acidosis, lipemia, and death.

It is the IV agent of choice for

  • Induction of anesthesia for neuro anesthesia and other surgeries
  • Maintenance of anesthesia in patients undergoing cardiac surgery.
  • Sedation for mechanical ventilation and minor procedures in the ICU.
  • Total iv anesthesia (TIVA) and short-term anesthesia for ambulatory surgeries 
  • Malignant hyperthermia

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man involved in a road traffic accident was brought to the emergency room. His vitals are as shown below. His vitals did not improve on fluid resuscitation. On FAST examination, there was fluid present in the retroperitoneal space. The patient was shifted to the operating room for laparotomy. What is the intravenous agent of choice for this patient?
  • Pulse rate- 100 bpm
  • Blood pressure(BP)- 80/40 mmHg
  • SpO2- 95%
  • Respiratory rate- 30 per minute
  • GCS- 15/15

(FAST- Focussed Assessment of Sonography in Trauma)
questions.solution:
Ketamine is the intravenous agent of choice in this patient. Ketamine indirectly stimulates the cardiovascular system and is thus useful in this patient as he has come with a traumatic injury to the abdomen and is hemodynamically unstable.

Ketamine is a phencyclidine derivative that inhibits NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptors resulting in a decrease in excitatory stimulation by glutamate in the brain. It is a strong analgesic and amnestic agent. It also causes dissociative anesthesia.

On the cardiovascular system, it directly has a cardio-depressive effect and indirectly stimulates it by activating the sympathetic system and inhibiting the vagus nerve. It predominantly shows a stimulatory effect hence causing tachycardia, increased cardiac output, and increased systemic and pulmonary hypertension.

On the respiratory system, it has a bronchodilator effect on bronchial smooth muscles. It increases salivary secretion and bronchial secretion. It also acts on other systems and increases the intracranial and intraocular pressures.

Uses:

  • Ketamine is the intravenous agent of choice for patients with shock, low cardiac output states, and reactive airway diseases.
  • It is also used in patients with congenital heart diseases, especially with right-to-left shunts
  • Perioperative analgesia

Ketamine should be avoided in patients with a history of seizures, psychiatric illness, or vascular aneurysms. It is also contraindicated in open eye injuries and eye surgeries

Adverse effects:

  • Hallucination is the most common side effect of ketamine.
  • Emergence reaction (vivid dreaming, illusion, etc)
  • Increases brain oxygen consumption and metabolic rate leading to increased intracranial tension.

Other options:

Option B: Propofol is the most commonly used parenteral anesthetic. It is cerebro-protective by decreasing cerebral metabolic rate. It produces dose-dependent hypotension.

Option C: Thiopentone belongs to the barbiturate group. It is cerebro-protective and is an anticonvulsant. It leads to hypotension due to vasodilation. It is contraindicated in patients with obstructive airway disease, severe cardiovascular instability, and shock, history of porphyrias.

Option D: Midazolam is a benzodiazepine. It is used in treating seizures and is used in daycare surgeries as an induction agent due to its short half-life.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is complaining of a nagging headache after undergoing a Caesarian section under spinal anesthesia. The headache is occipital in nature, worsens on standing, and is relieved by lying flat. What is the definitive management in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH). The definitive treatment for post-dural puncture headache is an epidural blood patch. 

PDPH can occur after spinal or epidural anesthesia due to loss of CSF through the dura which causes traction on the pain-sensitive intracranial structures. It may also occur due to compensatory, painful intracranial vasodilation to offset the reduction in intracranial pressure. The headache is typically frontal or occipital in distribution and is associated with nausea, neck stiffness, and lower back pain. Most of the headaches resolve spontaneously within 7 days. 

An epidural blood patch is the definitive management. It is ideally performed 24 hours after dural puncture and the development of classic symptoms. 15-20 mL of autologous blood is injected into the epidural space at the same or one interspace below the level of the dural puncture. It acts by stopping the CSF leak by either mass effect or coagulation. Most patients will respond to a single blood patch, and 90% of initial nonresponders will obtain relief from a second injection (1 to 2 days after the first). A prophylactic epidural patch is not recommended.

Related Pearl: PDPH- Post-Dural Puncture Headache

  • May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).
  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

  • Supine position
  • IV fluids
  • Caffeine and analgesia
  • Epidural blood patch

Related Pearl: Factors That Can Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Age: Younger, more frequent
  • Sex: Females > males
  • Needle size: Larger > smaller
  • Needle bevel: Less when the needle bevel is placed in the long axis of the neuraxis Orienting a needle bevel parallel with the axis of the spine, such that the longitudinal fibers of the dura would more likely be separated than cut, results in a lower incidence of postspinal puncture headache
  • Pregnancy: More when pregnant
  • Dural punctures: More with multiple punctures

Factors That Do Not Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Insertion and use of catheters for continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Timing of ambulation

questions.text:
You see an elderly man collapse in a shopping mall. He has no pulse. What is the correct sequence to be followed to provide cardio-pulmonary resuscitation to him?
  1. Call for the emergency response team
  2. Check scene safety
  3. Recheck pulse
  4. Chest compressions
questions.solution:
The correct sequence to be followed to provide cardio-pulmonary resuscitation (CPR) to the elderly man is 2-1-4-3.

For a patient in respiratory and cardiac distress, CAB-D (Circulation, Airway, Breathing, Defibrillate) must be assessed:

  1. Assess to make sure the scene is safe for you to attend to the patient.
  2. Assess responsiveness: Speak to the adult and ask if they are ok. Simultaneously look at the chest and abdomen for movement and normal breathing. 
  3. If the patient is unresponsive, call the emergency response team and bring an automatic external defibrillator (AED) to the patient or ask someone nearby to do so.
  4. Place the patient supine on a hard flat surface.
  5. Check for a carotid pulse for 5-10 sec.
  6. If the patient does not have a pulse, proceed with 5 cycles of CPR (lasting approximately 2 minutes).
    • Start with chest compressions:
      • Provide 100-120 compressions per min.
      • Place palms midline, one over the other, on the lower 1/3rd of the patient’s sternum between the nipples.
      • Press to a depth of 2-2.4 inches (5-6 cm) on the patient’s chest.
      • Press hard and fast.
      • Ensure full chest recoil with each compression.
    • Provide 2 rescue breaths for every 30 chest compressions (1 cycle of adult CPR is 30 chest compressions to 2 rescue breaths).
    • Recheck pulse every 2 min.
  7. If the patient has a pulse:
    • Provide 10 rescue breaths per min (1 breath every 6 sec).
    • Recheck pulse every 2 min.
  8. Once the AED arrives, analyze the rhythm for defibrillation:
    • If the rhythm is shockable, assure no one is near the patient, press the shock button, and resume 5 cycles of CPR.
    • If the rhythm is not shockable, initiate 5 cycles of CPR and recheck the rhythm.

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below. 

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is posted for surgery under general anesthesia. Which of the following inhalational agent cannot be used for induction of anesthesia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Desflurane cannot be used for the induction of anesthesia in this patient since it produces laryngospasm when used for inhalational anesthesia. Laryngospasm is because of the pungent nature of the gas. The incidence of laryngospasm following desflurane induction is almost 50%.

Desflurane has a rapid onset of action and also rapid emergence from anesthesia. Therefore, it is of particular value in neurosurgical and spinal fusion procedures where rapid awakening is required for neurological function assessment. It is also used for the maintenance of anesthesia.  Desflurane has no hepatic metabolism.

Other options:

Option A: Halothane is the preferred drug for gaseous induction of anesthesia in children. However, the incidence of halothane hepatitis and myocardial depression has reduced its use in children.

Option B: Sevoflurane is the preferred inhalational agent for induction in the pediatric age group. Cardiovascular depression, bradycardia, and arrhythmias are less frequent with sevoflurane than with halothane and hence the former is preferred.

Option D: Nitrous oxide is the least potent as it has the highest minimum alveolar concentration. It is combined with other potent inhaled anesthetics to reduce their dose. It can be used to hasten the induction of anesthesia along with other induction agents.

  • Neonatal circumcision is done under General anesthesia.

    • Causes-strabismus surgery, cataract surgery, enucleation, ocular trauma, retinal detachment surgery.
    • Manifestation-bradycardia (most common)
    • Treatment-temporary cessation surgery until heart rate increases, IV Atropine.
  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy :
    • High risk for malignant hyperthermia so succinyl choline and halothane should be avoided
    • Choice of anesthesia is propofol, nitrous oxide for maintenance.

questions.text: In adults, at which vertebral level does the spinal cord end?
questions.solution:
In adults, the spinal cord ends at the level of lower border of L1 vertebra.

Proximally, the spinal cord is continuous with the brain stem. Distally, it terminates in the conus medullaris as the filum terminale (fibrous extension) and the cauda equina (neural extension).

The lumbar puncture during spinal anesthesia (a.k.a. sub-arachnoid block, intra-thecal block) is done below the level of L1 in adults (L2-3, L3-4, L4-5 interspace), to avoid potential needle trauma to the spinal cord.

questions.text: As an intern during ICU posting, you see a patient on controlled ventilation using the instrument seen in the image below. The circuit is a modification of which breathing system?
questions.solution:
The device shown in the given image is the Bain circuit, which is a coaxial version of Mapleson class D.

The Mapleson systems A-F are breathing systems with certain features similar to those of the circle system:

  • Use of fresh gas flow
  • Supply of gas from a reservoir to meet inspiratory requirements
  • Elimination of CO2

However, they differ from the circle system by having bidirectional gas flow and lacking an absorber.

Components of Mapleson systems include: 

  • Connection point to a facemask or endotracheal tube
  • Reservoir tubing
  • Fresh gas inflow tubing
  • Expiratory pop-off valve or port

The Mapleson D, E, and F systems (or the T-piece group) are commonly used. Here, fresh gas enters near the patient, and excess gas is removed at the other end of the circuit.

The Bain circuit, a coaxial modification of the Mapleson D system, incorporates an inner fresh gas tube within an outer corrugated hose. Fresh gas enters near the reservoir bag and exits into the circuit at the patient’s end. Exhaled gases pass down the corrugated hose around the central tubing and are removed through the pop-off valve near the reservoir bag.

The advantage of this system is that the fresh gas acquires heat from the warmer exhaled gases through concurrent heat exchange. The disadvantage is kinking of the inner fresh gas tubing, resulting in inadequate gas flow and hypercapnia. To prevent this, the outer corrugated tube should be transparent to allow periodic inspection of the inner tube.

questions.text:
An intern in the anesthesia department was asked about the use of absorbents like soda lime in breathing systems. Which of the following statements are true regarding soda lime?
  1. Soda lime is less commonly used than barium hydroxide lime.
  2. The end products of the reaction of soda lime and CO2 are Na2CO3 + Ca(OH)2.
  3. The major constituent of soda lime is Ca(OH)2.
  4. Water content of soda lime is 5%.
  5. KOH is one of the components of soda lime.
questions.solution:
The statements that are true regarding soda lime are 3 and 5.

Soda lime is a CO2 absorbent used in the circle system (breathing system). It can absorb up to 23 L of CO2 per 100 g of absorbent. Its major constituent is Ca(OH)2 (80%). Other components include KOH, NaOH, and water (15%). It is also known as slaked lime.

A circle system is used in place of Mapleson circuits to avoid problems like loss of patient heat and humidity, waste of anesthetic agent due to high fresh gas flow, and pollution of the operating room environment. Components of this system are:

  1. CO2 absorber containing CO2 absorbent
  2. Fresh gas inlet
  3. Inspiratory unidirectional valve and inspiratory breathing tube
  4. Y-connector
  5. Expiratory unidirectional valve and expiratory breathing tube
  6. Adjustable pressure-limiting valve
  7. Reservoir

The reactions of soda lime granules with CO2 are as follows:

Step 1: CO2 + H2O (present on and within granules) → H2CO3

Step 2: 

  • H2CO3 + 2NaOH → Na2CO3 + 2H2O + Heat
  • H2CO3 + 2KOH → K2CO3 + 2H2O + Heat

All available strong bases are depleted.

Step 3:

  • Na2CO3 + Ca(OH)2 → CaCO3 (insoluble) + 2NaOH + Heat
  • K2CO3 + Ca(OH)2 → CaCO3 (insoluble) + 2KOH + Heat

NaOH and KOH are regenerated in this step, thereby acting as catalysts. This is the rate-limiting step since the NaOH and KOH regenerated in this step are required for step 2 for additional CO2 to be dissolved in water (step 1). Byproducts of this entire reaction are water and heat.

A pH indicator dye changes color from white to purple due to increasing H+ concentration and absorbent depletion. The absorbent should be replaced when 50-70% has changed color.

Absorbent granules can absorb and later release volatile anesthetics. This property is enhanced by the increased dryness of soda lime. Volatile anesthetics can be broken down to CO, resulting in clinically significant CO poisoning. Another absorbent, barium hydroxide lime, is no longer used due to the risk of fire in the system.

Related Pearl: Composition of CO2 Absorbers in rebreathing system

  • Ca(OH)2 - 80%
  • NaOH - 3%
  • KOH - 2%
  • Silica - 0.2%
  • Moisture-  14-19%

Granule size is 4-8 mesh

Absorbs up to 23L of CO2/100 g

With Trilene, soda-lime forms neurotoxin dichloroacetylene and pulmonary irritant phosgene gas; hence contraindicated.

Sevoflurane reacts with soda lime and produces Compound A

Method of hardness- Silica

  • Ca Cl2
  • CaSO4

Causes less degradation of volatile anesthetics eg. Sevoflurane to Compound A or Desflurane to Carbon Monoxide

  • Ba(OH)2 20%
  • KOH <1%

Absorbs up to 9-18L of CO2/100 g

Desflurane can be broken down to CO by dry barium hydroxide lime.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true regarding the combined spinal-epidural needle?

choices.text: It has slower onset of action
It  does not allow for increasing of block height
It is used commonly in obstetric anesthesia
It is not used for immediate pain relief

questions.solution:
The combined spinal-epidural (CSE) anesthesia is most widely used in obstetric anesthesia in labor. 

Combined spinal-epidural allows for clinical flexibility, with a rapid onset of action from the spinal block and a longer duration of analgesia and anesthesia with the epidural catheter. The epidural catheter can be left in situ to manage post-operative pain.  

When CSE is used during labor, an opioid and a local anesthetic are introduced via the spinal route for immediate pain relief. The epidural catheter is used for continued pain relief and operative intervention (if required). 

It has the advantage of dose flexibility, as the target block height can be reached by topping up the drug via the epidural catheter when required. This allows a lower dose of spinal anesthetic to be given initially.

Additional use is in increasing block height. This can be done by additional infiltration of a local anesthetic or saline to the epidural space via the catheter in a patient on the spinal block. questions.text: A 23-year-old patient admitted to the intensive medical care unit with suspected meningoencephalitis is undergoing the procedure shown below. All the following structures are pierced during this procedure, except ________.
questions.solution:
The patient is undergoing a procedure of lumbar puncture as shown in the image. All the given structures are pierced during lumbar puncture, except the posterior longitudinal ligament.

Lumbar puncture is a diagnostic procedure done to obtain a sample of cerebrospinal fluid from the subarachnoid space. The following structures are pierced during lumbar puncture, in that order:

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Supraspinous ligament
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum
  • Epidural space
  • Dura
  • Arachnoid
  • Subarachnoid space 

Indications:

  • Diagnosis of suspected meningitis and subarachnoid hemorrhage 
  • Spinal anesthesia and intrathecal administration of antibiotics/ chemotherapy
  • Therapeutic relief of pseudomotor cerebri, less frequently

Contraindications for lumbar puncture include:

  • Absolute- Infection over the site 
  • Relative-
    • Coagulopathy
    • Raised intracranial pressure
    • Spinal epidural abscess

Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) is a common post-procedure symptom. It occurs due to loss of CSF through the dura which causes traction on the pain-sensitive intracranial structures. The headache in PDPH is typically frontal or occipital. It is aggravated with the upright or sitting posture and is relieved by lying supine. 

Other complications include infections, bleeding, cerebral herniation, and radicular pain.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman undergoing surgery was intubated after administering rocuronium for neuromuscular blockade. Before anesthesia induction, a mechanosensor was incorporated with electrodes, as shown in the image below. The contraction of which muscle does it assess to monitor neuromuscular activity?
questions.solution:
The mechanosensor with electrodes is placed over the region of the ulnar nerve, thus assessing the contraction of the adductor pollicis muscle to monitor neuromuscular activity.

Monitoring of neuromuscular blockade is required to monitor the blockade intraoperatively, ensure its complete reversal postoperatively, and prevent residual blockade. To monitor the neuromuscular function, a peripheral motor nerve is supramaximally stimulated and the response of the muscle is assessed.

The most commonly assessed nerve-muscle unit is the ulnar nerve-adductor pollicis muscle. This is because it is easily accessible, has the lowest risk of direct muscle stimulation, and the response can be evaluated tactilely, visually, or by objective methods. To stimulate the ulnar nerve, the electrodes are best applied to the volar aspect of the wrist.

Other nerve-muscle units that can be assessed include:

  • Posterior tibial nerve-flexor hallucis brevis muscle
  • Facial nerve-orbicularis oculi muscle
  • Facial nerve-corrugator supercilii muscle

Many methods can be used for objective monitoring of neuromuscular function:

  • Mechanomyography (MMG)
  • Electromyography (EMG)
  • Acceleration of the muscle response (AMG)
  • Kinemyography (KMG)
  • Cuff pressure modality (CPM)
  • Compressomyography (CMG)
  • Phonomyography (PMG)

The image shows AMG, which is based on Newton’s second law: force = mass × acceleration. It measures the isotonic acceleration of the stimulated muscle.

questions.text: A G2P1 lady with 37 weeks of gestation is in active labor. You assist your labor room resident in giving a pudendal block. The resident explains that you have to approach the nerve by identifying a particular surface landmark. The landmark for this nerve block is:
questions.solution:
The ischial spine is the landmark for the pudendal nerve block. This is because the pudendal nerve is accessible here as it passes below the sacrospinous ligament at the level of attachment of the ligament to the ischial spine.

Sensory nerve fibers of the pudendal nerve arise from S2, S3, and S4 nerves. Pudendal nerve blocks in combination with local anesthetic are used to provide perineal anesthesia during the second stage of labor.

Here, a special needle (Koback)  and a guide (Iowa trumpet) are used. The needle is placed transvaginally underneath the ischial spine on each side and is advanced 1 to 1.5 cm through the sacrospinous ligament. 10 mL of 1% lidocaine or 2% chloroprocaine is used for the procedure.

The pudendal nerve block can be used for:

  • Analgesia during the second stage of labor. A pudendal block is used when there are contraindications to epidural/ spinal anesthesia or if there is a need for low vaginal and perineal anesthesia.
  • Episiotomy repair
  • Minor procedures of the lower vagina and perineum.
  • Instrumental delivery.

The complications of the procedure are accidental intravascular injection, retro-psoas abscess, subgluteal abscess, and retroperitoneal hematoma.

Also, note that the pudendal block does not impact the cervix or upper vagina and is ineffective for pain relief associated with uterine manipulation.

questions.text: During recovery from anesthesia, which of the following drugs cannot be used for reversal of neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A middle aged man presents with complaints of shortness of breath, chest pain and cough. The following catheter is being used to evaluate the patient for pulmonary hypertension. Identify the catheter.
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the Swan-Ganz catheter used for pulmonary artery catheterization. It is also called the pulmonary artery catheter and is used to diagnose and evaluate pulmonary artery hypertension.

The standard pulmonary artery catheter is 110 cm long with a 7.0 – 9.0 Fr circumference. It contains 4 internal lumens. The distal port is used to measure PAP (pulmonary artery pressure) while the 2nd port is used to measure CVP (central venous pressure).

Pulmonary artery catheterization is a diagnostic procedure in which a catheter is passed through the central vein, into the right atrium and the right ventricle, and then is finally placed in the pulmonary artery.

The indications include:

  • Evaluation of pulmonary artery hypertension
  • Measurement of pressures in the right atrium, right ventricle, and pulmonary artery
  • Assessment of etiology and volume status in shock
  • Assessment of congenital heart disease, cardiac shunts, and right-sided valvular disease

Complications :

  • Catheterization related:
    1. Arrhythmias, ventricular fibrillation
    2. Right bundle branch block, complete heart block
  • Catheter residence related:
    1. Mechanical, catheter knots
    2. Thromboembolism
    3. Pulmonary infarction
    4. Infection, endocarditis
    5. Endocardial damage, cardiac valve injury
    6. Pulmonary artery rupture
    7. Pulmonary artery pseudoaneurysm
  • Others:
    1. Misinterpretation of data
    2. Misuse of equipment

All the other catheters mentioned are used for establishing a central venous line for long-term total parenteral nutrition, medications, etc.

questions.text: A senior resident working in an intensive care unit has assembled the following equipment to perform a procedure. Which of the following procedures he would be performing?
questions.solution:
From the materials which have been gathered by the senior resident, it can be inferred that he would be performing a central venous catheterization.

The image below shows the equipment for performing a central venous catheterization.

The instruments are numbered as follows:

  1. A syringe with a local anesthetic
  2. Scalpel in case venous cutdown is needed
  3. Introducer needle on the syringe with saline to detect backflow of blood upon vein penetration
  4. Guidewire
  5. Tissue dilator
  6. An indwelling catheter
  7. Additional fasteners, and corresponding surgical thread

The catheter can be inserted into any of the following veins - Right and internal jugular veins, subclavian vein, external jugular veins, and femoral vein.

Indications of central venous catheterization include

  • Central venous pressure monitoring
  • Pulmonary artery catheterization and monitoring
  • Transvenous cardiac pacing
  • Temporary hemodialysis
  • Drug administration (concentrating vasoactive drugs, hyperalimentation, chemotherapy, agents irritating peripheral veins, prolonged antibiotic therapy)

  • Sampling site for repeated blood testing

  • Arterial puncture - This is the most common mechanical complication.

  • Chylothorax - This can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common.
  • Injury to the associated nerves - like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords.
  • Thromboembolism - This can lead to venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. It is more common with femoral veins.
  • Infections - most common late complication.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man was brought to the casualty with palpitations and dizziness. His heart rate was 160/min and blood pressure was 110/80 mm Hg. His ECG is given below. What is the first line of management?
questions.solution:
The patient has paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia. As the patient's blood pressure is normal and there is no evidence of hemodynamic deterioration, initial treatment consists of vagal maneuvers (Valsalva maneuver) in awake patients. This is because vagal maneuvers alone can terminate approximately 20% to 25% of reentry supraventricular tachycardias (SVTs).

If this is unsuccessful, then IV adenosine 6 mg is given. If necessary another dose of adenosine 12 mg may be administered after 1-2 minutes.

If the drug is administered via a central venous catheter, then these doses are reduced to 3 mg and 6 mg, respectively.

If there is hemodynamic deterioration, then cardioversion is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient was posted for unilateral mastectomy for breast carcinoma. Halothane was used as the inhalational agent. Intraoperatively, she develops fever and tachycardia. On physical examination, rigidity was noted in the masseter muscle. What is the drug of choice for the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient developing fever, tachycardia, and rigidity of the masseter muscle after being administered halothane is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia. The drug of choice for the condition is dantrolene.

Dantrolene is a direct-acting skeletal muscle relaxant that acts on the RyR1 (ryanodine receptor) calcium channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal muscles and inhibits calcium-induced calcium release. This results in the uncoupling of membrane depolarization and muscle contraction, thus inhibiting muscle contraction.

Malignant hyperthermia is a genetic condition in which mutated RyR1 receptors are present in the skeletal muscles. In the presence of certain triggers, this mutated RyR1 causes severe dysfunction in the RyR1 channels. This leads to the accumulation of calcium ions in the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction, rigidity, increased heat production, acidosis, hyperkalemia, and increased end-tidal CO2. Patients with positive family history and patients with congenital myopathies are at increased risk for the development of this condition.

Drugs triggering malignant hyperthermia:

  • Succinylcholine
  • Halothane
  • Isoflurane
  • Sevoflurane

Dantrolene sodium is the drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia. Once the diagnosis is made, the causative inhalational agent should be stopped immediately. Supportive management includes rapid cooling, inhalation of 100% oxygen, control of acidosis, and treatment of hyperkalemia.

Other options:

Options A and C: Succinylcholine and isoflurane are known to cause malignant hyperthermia, and hence cannot be used for the management.

Option D: Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing skeletal muscle relaxant. It is not indicated for the management of malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: Which of the following drug combinations is preferred for providing epidural analgesia during labour?
questions.solution:
The preferred combination used for epidural analgesia during labour is bupivacaine with fentanyl.

This is because, doses of local anaesthetics can be reduced by combining them with opioids like fentanyl or sufentanil.

The lesser concentration of local anaesthetic used leads to greater preservation of motor function and makes ambulation of the patient possible (walking or mobile epidural). Also, by reducing the concentration of the drugs, adverse effects like hypotension and drug toxicity are minimized.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient has to undergo incisional hernia surgery under general anesthesia. She complains of awareness in her past caesarean section. Which of the following monitoring techniques can be used to prevent such awareness?
questions.solution:

The bispectral index is a monitoring technique to check the depth of anesthesia using an algorithm by a device. Individual intraoperative awareness is evaluated. It utilizes parameters like EEG signals, eye blinking, etc.

  2. High-frequency beta activation (as found during light anesthesia)
  3. Suppressed EEG waves
  4. Burst suppression

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient underwent liposuction under local anesthesia. A few hours after the procedure, he presented with complaints of lassitude, shortness of breath, and slate grey cyanosis. The patient is started on 100 % oxygen, but the pulse oximeter still shows a saturation of 85%. Which of the following local anesthetic agents can most likely be attributed to his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with refractory hypoxemia (no change in saturation even on oxygen supplementation) points to a diagnosis of methemoglobinemia. The local anesthetic agent which can be attributed to his symptoms is prilocaine.

Prilocaine is metabolized to o-toluidine in the liver, which converts hemoglobin (Fe 2+) to methemoglobin (Fe 3+), hence producing methemoglobinemia. Therefore, the use of prilocaine is limited to dental procedures.

Methemoglobinemia is characterized by cyanosis which does not respond to oxygen administration. On examination, slate grey/ brownish pseudocyanosis can be seen.

Interestingly, pulse oximetry in methemoglobinemia shows a plateau of 80% to 85% irrespective of the arterial oxygen saturation and the methemoglobin levels. Co-oximeters which can differentiate methemoglobin from carboxyhemoglobin, oxyhemoglobin, and deoxyhemoglobin are thus preferred. Treatment of methemoglobinemia includes reduction of methemoglobin to hemoglobin by intravenous methylene blue (1–2 mg/kg).

Note: Benzocaine used in topical local anesthetic sprays can also cause methemoglobinemia.

questions.text: As a first-year anesthesia resident, you intubate a patient for general anesthesia. After placement of the endotracheal tube, your senior performs capnography, which reveals the following graph. What is the likely possibility?
questions.solution:
The likely possibility causing the above capnographic waveform is oesophagal intubation. In oesophageal intubation, there is an initial peak of the graph showing end-tidal CO2 due to some amount of swallowed expired air present in the stomach. Subsequently, the graph approaches zero due to wash out of this swallowed air in a few breaths.

Capnography is the measurement and graphical representation of the concentration or partial pressure of carbon dioxide at the airway opening. It uses the technique of infrared light absorption by CO2 by the principle of Beer-Lambert law.

The presence of carbon dioxide in the expired air reveals the functioning of the patient's ventilation, pulmonary blood flow and aerobic metabolism. Thus, it can be used to monitor the correct placement of an airway device, the adequacy of cardiac output, as well as the integrity of a breathing circuit. Capnography can be used to:

  • Assess tracheal tube and tracheostomy patency and position
  • Monitor adequate ventilator support
  • Percutaneous tracheostomy placement
  • Monitoring patients with increased intracranial pressure
  • Monitoring response to treatment of bronchospasm
  • Estimation of cardiac output
  • During cardiac arrest

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient was posted for elective appendicectomy. He has a history of myocardial infarction and his echocardiography revealed a reduced ejection fraction.  Which of the following induction agents is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario with a history of myocardial infarction and reduced ejection fraction, etomidate is considered the most appropriate induction agent.

Etomidate is a rapid onset, intravenous anesthetic agent used for induction in patients with cardiovascular disease, reactive airway disease, and intracranial hypertension. Etomidate has minimal effect on cardiovascular function due to its lack of effect on the sympathetic nervous system and on the function of the baroreceptors. They act on alpha 2 adrenoreceptors and increase blood pressure which helps to maintain cardiovascular stability after the induction. 

It is used as a short-term sedative in hemodynamically unstable patients, like those requiring cardioversion or patients with unstable angina, for minor operative procedures. Long-term use of etomidate in trauma or terminally ill patients is not advised as there is associated adrenocortical suppression leading to reduced blood pressure.

Other options:

Option A- Ketamine has a stimulatory effect on the sympathetic nervous system and results in increased blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output. This leads to an increase in myocardial oxygen consumption and so it is contraindicated in ischemic heart disease.

Option C- Propofol is a myocardial depressant agent. It reduces sympathetic activity, leading to vasodilatation that results in a reduction of blood pressure and a decrease in cardiac output.

Option D- Thiopentone is also a myocardial depressant agent. It causes peripheral vasodilatation, reduction in ventricular filling, and decreased cardiac contractility. This results in a reduction in blood pressure and a decrease in cardiac output.

questions.text: During casualty rotations, you see a  patient who suddenly went into apnea, being ventilated with the following apparatus. What does the part marked as A represent?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a self-inflating bag and mask and the part marked as A represents the oxygen inlet.

Bag and mask ventilation is used as the first step in airway management to provide positive pressure ventilation. It serves as a rescue technique to provide oxygenation and ventilation in patients with difficult airways until tracheal intubation is achieved. 

The bag in this apparatus is a self-inflating bag. This allows for it to be used without a pressurized gas supply and is delivered to the patient when the bag is squeezed (compressed). A patent airway and a good seal are essential to facilitate bag and mask ventilation.

The face mask can be used by two techniques:

  • One-handed technique: Most commonly used technique. This is achieved by ensuring a tight seal with the left-hand thumb and index finger forming a 'C' around the collar of the mask. The third and fourth digits are placed on the ramus of the mandible, and the fifth digit placed below the angle of the mandible helps in jaw thrust.
  • Two-handed technique: This is used in cases of difficult airways and it requires assistance.

Signs of effective ventilation:

  • Chest rise on squeezing the bag
  • Condensation in the clear mask
  • Pulse oximetry
  • Capnography

Mask ventilation is usually contraindicated in patients with an increased risk of regurgitation. It should be used with caution in patients with severe facial trauma.

A 57-year-old male patient presents with a heart rate of 45 beats/minute and blood pressure of 70/40 mmHg. According to the ACLS criteria, what is the next best step in the management of this patient?

ACLS - Advanced Cardiac Life Support
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is that of bradycardia and according to the ACLS criteria, the next best step in the management of this patient is the administration of a single dose of atropine. 

Bradycardia is defined as a heart rate of less than 60 beats/ min. Those who present with bradycardia should be first stabilized with the following:

  • Maintain patient airway and breathing
  • Administer oxygen if breathlessness is present
  • Cardiac monitor and blood pressure to be monitored with oximetry
  • IV access to be placed
  • 12 lead ECG done 

Following the initial stabilization, the patient should be checked for hypotension, altered mental status, signs of shock, angina, and acute heart failure. If none are present, then the patient can be monitored. If any of the above are present, then atropine 0.5 mg must be administered. This must be repeated every 3-5 minutes up to a maximum dose of 3mg. Atropine inhibits the muscarinic effects of the parasympathetic nervous system.

If the maximum dose of atropine has been administered and there is no response, then the next step is to initiate one of the following: 

  • Transcutaneous pacing (Option B) OR
  • Dopamine infusion at 5-20 mcg/minute (Option C) OR
  • Epinephrine infusion at 2-10 mcg/minute (Option D)

If the patient is not responding to treatment then expert consultation and transvenous pacing must be done.

  • Maintaining a patent airway and assisting breathing as necessary
  • Administering oxygen if hypoxemic
  • Attaching cardiac monitor to identify rhythm; monitor blood pressure and oximetry
  • IV access
  • 12-Lead ECG

questions.text: During a preoperative anesthetic evaluation, pharmacologic stress echocardiography is being undertaken for a patient with chronic pulmonary disease. Which of the following agents can be used for inducing pharmacological stress in this patient?
questions.solution:
Dobutamine can be used for the induction of pharmacological stress in a patient with chronic pulmonary disease.

Dobutamine is a potent β-receptor agonist used for stress testing. It increases myocardial oxygen demand by increasing contractility, heart rate, and blood pressure in a similar manner as exercise. Dobutamine stress testing is the preferred choice for the assessment of myocardial viability and is generally used as an alternative to vasodilator stress in patients with chronic pulmonary disease, where vasodilators are contraindicated.  

Cardiac stress testing is performed in patients with known or suspected coronary artery disease. It is also done for preoperative CVS monitoring in a patient with risk factors for myocardial infarction. Generally, exercise stress testing is preferred because it provides information on functional capacity, exercise tolerance, and symptom provocation. However, some patients undergo pharmacologic stress testing. Indications for pharmacologic stress testing include: 

  • Unstable angina
  • Inability to exercise
  • History of uncontrolled heart failure at risk for deterioration
  • Poorly controlled blood pressure
  • History of aortic stenosis
  • Recent myocardial infarction
  • Acute pulmonary embolism
  • Acute pericarditis or myocarditis
  • Severe pulmonary hypertension
  • Chronic pulmonary disease

Vasodilators are the most commonly used pharmacologic stressors for myocardial perfusion imaging. Vasodilator stress acts by increasing and diverting blood flow to the non-diseased blood vessels so that the diseased vessels can be visualized clearly. It is brought about by drugs such as adenosine, dipyridamole, and regadenoson.

Contraindications to vasodilator stress testing are:

  • Pronounced active bronchospastic airway disease
  • Significant hypotension

questions.text: During your ICU posting, your senior resident advises you to extubate the patients, who are on mechanical ventilation and are found to be improving. In order to plan for weaning, the rapid shallow breathing index of the patient should be:
questions.solution:
Rapid shallow breathing index (RSBI) should be less than 100.

Patients with an RSBI <100 are eligible candidates for successful extubation. But, those with an RSBI >120 will need some degree of mechanical ventilator support.

A patient on mechanical ventilation should be tried to wean off when the patient no longer requires the ventilator. This condition usually met when the patient can breathe spontaneously, is hemodynamically stable with adequate arterial oxygen saturation, and when he has a pH >7.25.

  • Inspiratory pressure: -20-30cm H2O
  • Tidal volume: 4-6ml/kg
  • Vital capacity: >10 mL/kg
  • Minute ventilation: <10 L/min
  • Rapid shallow breathing index(RSBI): <100

Patients are weaned off from the ventilator with the help of techniques such as pressure support, synchronized intermittent mandatory ventilation (SIMV), and periods of spontaneous breathing (either on a Τ-piece or on a low setting of CPAP).

The image shows a local anesthetic being injected into the tip of the axilla around the axillary artery. This is the method used to perform the axillary block. The nerves blocked are the ulnar, radial, and median nerves. 

The axillary block is used for elbow and distal upper extremity anesthesia. The most important landmark is the pulse of the axillary artery just distal to the pectoralis major near the anterior axillary wall. Usually, the median, ulnar, and radial nerves (close the arterial wall) and the musculocutaneous nerve (showing a characteristic medial-to-lateral course in the axilla) can be seen.

Although this is a safe and effective technique, the musculocutaneous nerve fails to be blocked as it changes its course from adjacent the axillary artery to within the coracobrachialis muscle and then exiting the muscle. questions.text:
While administering an axillary nerve block for a patient, the resident accidentally injects the anesthetic agent into the axillary artery. Which of the following co-morbidities if present can accentuate the condition?
  1. Increased age
  2. Hypercapnia
  3. Renal failure
  4. Metabolic alkalosis
  5. Cardiac failure
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST). Increased age, hypercapnia, renal failure, and cardiac failure can accentuate LAST. Acidosis (respiratory or metabolic), and not alkalosis, can also increase LAST.

LAST can occur due to inadvertent injection of a local anesthetic (LA), intravascular migration of a catheter used for continuous LA infusion, and absorption from the mucus membranes and the GI tract when swallowed (used during bronchoscopy).

The risk factors for LAST are:

  • Extremes of age: Infants and the elderly
  • End organ dysfunction: Cardiac disease, renal insufficiency, hepatic disease
  • Metabolic disturbances: Acidosis, hypoxia, hypercarbia
  • Pregnancy

LAST affects the following systems:

  • Central nervous system (CNS): LAs predominantly block the cortical inhibitory pathways, thereby causing excitatory symptoms and signs like a metallic taste, perioral numbness, mental status changes, visual changes, muscle twitching, and seizures. Further increase in blood levels causes CNS depression, leading to respiratory depression and coma. 
  • Cardiovascular system (CVS): Bradycardia and hypotension are usually seen. Cardiovascular toxicity may progress to ventricular arrhythmias, asystole, conduction disturbances, impaired cardiac contractility, and loss of vascular tone.

Management includes:

  • Stop administration of the agent
  • Arrange for cardiopulmonary bypass
  • Manage airway to prevent hypoxia and acidosis
  • Suppress seizures with appropriate medication (benzodiazepine is preferred) to improve oxygenation
  • Provide cardiovascular support with appropriate medication (amiodarone for arrhythmia) to maintain coronary perfusion
  • Administer 20% lipid emulsion:
    • Rapid administration of bolus lipid emulsion over 2-3 min
    • Begin infusion based on patient's body weight
    • Repeat bolus and double the infusion rate for persistent cardiovascular toxicity
    • Continue infusion for at least 10 min after hemodynamic stability is achieved

questions.text: A middle-aged man is posted for an open cholecystectomy. He has a medical history of hypercholesterolemia. The pre-anesthetic evaluation revealed abnormal liver function tests and mild hepatomegaly. Which of the following muscle relaxants can be safely used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Atracurium can be safely used in this patient with liver disease because of non-hepatic metabolism.

Atracurium and cis-atracurium undergo plasma ester hydrolysis and Hofmann elimination at physiological pH and temperature. Hofmann elimination is a spontaneous, non-enzymatic, chemical degradation. So, the clearance of atracurium and cis-atracurium is independent of liver or kidney function. Hence, they are the agents of choice in patients with liver disease and/or renal failure.

The metabolites of atracurium and cis-atracurium are monoquaternary acrylate and laudanosine.

Some of the adverse effects of atracurium are hypotension, tachycardia, and allergic reactions (bronchospasm) due to a dose-dependent histamine release. On the other hand, these adverse effects are not seen with cis-atracurium and so it is preferred over the former.

questions.text: The mask given below is preferred in which of the following patients?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a venturi mask and it is preferred in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

There is hypoventilation in patients with COPD and they require greater FiO2 than those provided by low-flow devices. Thus, they are ideal candidates for the use of a Venturi mask. The Venturi mask uses the Bernoulli principle to deliver a predetermined and fixed concentration of oxygen to the patient that is based on the size of the constriction present in the device. A fixed oxygen concentration is delivered irrespective of the patient's respiratory pattern as it provides a higher gas flow than the peak inspiratory flow rate.

In the Venturi mask system, oxygen inflow is connected to a specific color-coded entrainment device at the base of the mask that provides a set Fio2 at a set oxygen inflow rate. The range provided by different devices is Fio2 of 0.24 to 0.5, oxygen inflow of 4 to 15 l/min, and the total flow delivered 35 to 45 l/min.

Disadvantages: Caution should be exercised when handling the mask as there can be an increase in the delivered FiO2 when the air entrainment ports are obstructed by the patient’s hands, bed sheets, or water condensate.

In cases of carbon monoxide inhalation, myocardial infarction, and trauma victims, non-rebreathing masks are preferred as they provide minimum oxygen flows of 10-15L/min which are required in cases of hypoxemia, but with normal respiratory efforts.

A retrobulbar block is a regional anesthesia technique used in ophthalmic surgery which involves the injection of a local anesthetic into the extraocular muscle cone. The needle penetrates the lower lid at the junction of the outer and middle third of the orbit. After aspiration to rule out intravascular injection, 2 to 5 mL of local anesthetic (lidocaine 2% or bupivacaine 0.75%) is injected, and the needle is removed.

Complications of retrobulbar block include:

  • Retrobulbar hemorrhage (most common complication) - Venous hemorrhage spreads slowly but arterial hemorrhage can produce a rapid swelling. This may compress surrounding vital structures and present with marked proptosis, immobility of the globe, inability to close the lids, and blood staining of the conjunctiva and the lids. Compression on the retinal vasculature can cause severe vision loss. 
  • Postretrobulbar block apnea syndrome: This may occur if the anesthetic is injected into the optic nerve sheath.
  • Perforation of the globe
  • Oculocardiac reflex
  • Accidental intravascular injection of the local anesthetic
  • Respiratory arrest

Contraindications of retrobulbar block:

  • Bleeding disorders - This is because of the risk of retrobulbar hemorrhage 
  • High myopia - Increased length of the globe increases the risk of perforation
  • Open eye injury (penetrating eye injury) - injection of local anesthetic behind the globe could increase the intraocular pressure which could lead to extrusion of the orbital contents.

Other options:

Option A: Retinal detachment: Can present with non-specific symptoms initially, but later present with photopsia (transient flashes of light), floaters (small moving spots in the retinal field), or a gradually developing veil/ curtain obscuring field of vision.

Option B: Subconjunctival haemorrhage: It is usually asymptomatic, but a momentary sharp pain or a snapping sensation can be felt. It is seen on elderly individuals and occurs either spontaneously or follows trauma, surgery or conjunctivitis.

Option C: Optic neuritis: It is characterised by loss of vision, deteriorating in hours to days, along with local tenderness. Often the vision improves spontaneously.

questions.solution:
The correctly matched muscle relaxants with their respective durations of action are 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B.

Neuromuscular blocking drugs (NMBDs) are administered to facilitate endotracheal intubation, mechanical ventilation, and various surgical procedures by relaxing skeletal muscles. However, they are not administered to prevent patient movement. There are two types of NMBDs:

  • Depolarizing: Succinylcholine is the only available depolarizing NMBD, characterized by rapid onset and ultrashort duration of action.
  • Non-depolarizing:
    • Many NMBDs are available, classified according to chemical class or duration of action.
    • They produce neuromuscular blockade by competing with acetylcholine for the postsynaptic α subunits.
    • The speed of onset is inversely proportional to the potency of the drug.
    • The normal neuromuscular function must return after the administration of the drug, using objective means of monitoring. Residual neuromuscular paralysis decreases esophageal tone and disrupts muscle coordination during swallowing.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium

questions.text: During the pre-anaesthetic evaluation of a patient, the oral cavity examined is depicted in the image given below. The image shows which class of the Mallampati score?
questions.solution:
The image of the oral cavity shows the soft palate and the base of the uvula, and is thus graded as Mallampati class III.

Mallampati classification is an important component of airway examination. It is used to assess the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate in an upright position with the patient's head neutral, mouth open, tongue protruded, and no phonation. 

Higher scores indicate poor visibility of these structures due to the presence of a large tongue. Thus, Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati classes III and IV are considered features of difficult airway.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

questions.text: How long should elective surgery be deferred for a patient who had cough and fever, after he has recovered from COVID-19, and had not required any hospitalization?
questions.solution:
A patient, who has recovered from COVID-19 and hadn’t required any hospitalization should be deferred from any elective surgery for a period of 6 weeks.

The American Society of Anesthesiologists has suggested the following duration of intervals for patients recovered from COVID-19. The wait time is from the date of diagnosis of COVID-19 to the date of surgery as follows:

  • 4 weeks: for an asymptomatic patient or recovery from only mild, non-respiratory symptoms.
  • 6 weeks: for a symptomatic patient (e.g: cough, dyspnea) who did not require hospitalization
  • 8-10 weeks: for a symptomatic patient who is hospitalized or who has comorbidities such as diabetes or who is immunocompromised.
  • 12 weeks: for a patient who was admitted in intensive care unit due to COVID-19 infection.

The ASA-PS helps in assessing the patient's risk of undergoing anesthesia and surgery. It also improves the physician's clinical decision making by identifying alternative treatment options and the extent of postoperative care and monitoring that may be required. It also helps in preparing for interventions that might need to be carried out in the case of deterioration. 

However, it does not consider the risks of the surgical procedure itself, resulting in postoperative complications and mortality when performed alone. Hence, a combination of assessment of the risks of the operative procedure and those of the patient's preoperative medical status must constitute the overall perioperative risk. Another limitation is that the ASA-PA classification shows a lot of subjectivity since different anesthesiologists would assign different categories to the same patient.

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification is used to define relative risk before conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient is posted for surgery under general anesthesia. She is on the second day of her menstrual cycle on the day of her surgery. She has a previous history of postoperative emesis and motion sickness. Which of the following should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario indicates that the patient has significant risk factors for postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV). Nitrous oxide is avoided in patients at high risk of PONV. 

PONV has an incidence of 20-30% in the general surgical population and 70-80% in those with predisposing risk factors. It is seen within 24 hours of discharge, usually in an ambulatory surgery patient.

Risk factors for PONV:

  • Patient factors 
    • Young age, female gender, particularly if menstruating on the day of surgery or in the first trimester of pregnancy
    • History of prior postoperative emesis
    • History of motion sickness
  • Anesthetic techniques
    • General anesthesia
    • Drugs: Opioids, Volatile agents, Nitrous oxide
  • Surgical procedures
    • Strabismus surgery
    • Ear surgery
    • Laparoscopy
    • Breast surgery
  • Postoperative factors
    • Postoperative pain
    • Hypotension

Drugs used in the prophylaxis and treatment of PONV:

  • 5-HT 3 antagonists - ondansetron, palonosetron
  • Butyrophenones- droperidol
  • Dexamethasone
  • Transdermal scopolamine

Note: Propofol has antiemetic property and thus reduces the risk of PONV.

Other options:

Option A: Opioids in themselves have high risk of causing PONV, however when combined with Ketamine there is a very significant reduction in the causation of PONV. Various meta-analysis have proven that when given given together ketamine reduces the opiate effects particularly PONV.

Option B: Propofol when given preoperatively helps reduce the incidence of PONV.The prophylactic administration of propofol as a maintenance anesthetic during breast surgery was found to be more effective in averting postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) than 4 mg of ondansetron.

Option D: Benzodiazepines such as Midazolam are known to reduce PONV. They are given to children to help reduce the incidence of PONV at a dose of 0.05mg/kg.

questions.text: While inducing anesthesia in a patient posted for neurosurgery, the consultant advises you to use an anesthetic agent with a lower MAC. The minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) of an inhaled anesthetic agent is a measure of its:
questions.solution:
The minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) of an inhalational anesthetic agent is an indicator of its potency. An anesthetic agent with a lower MAC is advised in this patient. The lower the MAC, the higher the potency. 

MAC is an account of the alveolar concentration of the anesthetic that prevents movement in 50% of patients in response to a standardized stimulus such as a surgical incision. It is representative of the partial pressure of the anesthetic in the brain and is helpful in the comparison of the potencies of different agents. MAC is relatively unaffected by species, sex, or duration of anesthesia.

MAC values (expressed as a '%' of 1 atmosphere) of some anesthetic agents are:

  • Halothane - 0.75
  • Isoflurane - 1.2
  • Sevoflurane - 2.0
  • Desflurane - 6.0
  • N2O - 105

Note: N2O is not used alone as a complete anesthetic agent, because of a high MAC. It is generally used in combination with the more potent agents. Such a combination will reduce the requirements of the other agents (65% nitrous oxide decreases the MAC of the volatile anesthetics by approximately 50%).

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients.
